abstract.p: Reed Elsevier reports first-half pretax profits of $529 million; says it will meet full-year earnings forecasts (S)

block.p: After two years of poor results, Reed Elsevier, the British-Dutch publisher that owns Lexis-Nexis and Variety, said it would meet its full-year earnings forecasts after a fall in first-half profits was lower than expected. The company is investing in online ventures as it pursues efforts to reduce costs. It said Internet spending had reduced first-half adjusted pretax profit to $:351 million ($529 million) from $:371 million a year earlier. Analysts had forecast profits of $:324 million to $:340 million. Reed Elsevier also said it was considering making an offer for Harcourt General, a textbook publisher, which was put up for sale in June.
